awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Emergence of terpene cyclization in animals
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemical interactions between organisms represent a key form of communication in nature and is mediated by diverse arrays of small molecules.  These molecules or chemical cues serve critical roles in maintaining and driving species diversity and ecosystem functions. Using interdisciplinary methods, the team of investigators explore the question of how chemical compounds emerge and adopt biological functions with a specific focus on understanding the emergence of terpenes - a major family of molecules used by insects to ward off enemies and pathogens, search for food, and attract or seek out mates. Integrating computational modeling and molecular modifications, the project reconstructs the evolution of enzymes that are central to the generation of terpene chemical diversity in insects. Through their study, the investigators will develop an integrated empirical and theoretical platform that will serve as a blueprint for tracing the evolution of various protein families.  The project has broader societal and educational impacts, including potential generation of target enzyme products and gene variants for industrial applications and translation of research results into a visual installation, which will be accessible to the general public through theaters at Virginia Tech and the Science Museum of Western Virginia. 

Terpenes constitute a large class of mostly cyclic molecules with major roles in chemical interactions of organisms. However, the emergence of enzymatic functions responsible for the cyclization and diversity of terpenes in animals has remained elusive. The research team will apply a combination of computational and experimental methods to define key enzymatic adaptations underlying terpene diversity in insects - the most species-rich lineage of animals. Specifically, the project defines modifications that activate terpene cyclase (TPS) enzymatic function in isoprenyl diphosphate synthases (IDS), enzymes involved in core terpene metabolism. Investigators will identify and functionally characterize terpene cyclase enzymes in diverse insect taxa to assess adaptive changes corresponding to the evolution of these enzymes in insects.  The functional data will be combined with protein structural analysis to generate models that pinpoint amino acid residue networks, which trigger the emergence of TPS activities on IDS templates. Network models will be used to construct synthetic enzyme libraries and help characterize mutational pathways that underlie terpene cyclization. Investigators will also use data from the study to develop integrated biophysical models of enzyme evolutionary dynamics that quantitatively describe fundamental transitions of enzyme function in the emergence of terpene diversity. Cumulatively, the insights from this interdisciplinary project will lead to an improved understanding of the biophysical principles behind major expansions of enzymatic and chemical diversity in nature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported a project aimed at reconstructing the evolutionary emergence of terpene-based chemical communication in insects. The premise for the project was based on the observation that insects have evolved a chemical language system using terpenes, the largest and most diverse collection of metabolites. Further, terpenes were previously thought to only be made by plants and microbes by enzymes called terpene synthases (TPSs). The discovery of insect TPSs raised many questions about how insects evolved a new branch of metabolism to make terpenes. What was clear is that insect TPS enzymes evolved from isoprenyl diphosphate synthases (IDSs), a class of enzymes in all organisms that build metabolites using 5-carbon building blocks to make essential metabolites. The driving questions is how. What changes in gene sequences were essential for converting insect IDS into TPS enzymes? Further, did this evolutionary change happen once in a single insect progenitor or multiple times in diverse insect lineages?

We assembled available protein structure data, downloaded available insect TPS and IDS sequences from UniProt (an online resource for protein sequences), and curated our data collection to initiate the project. Our data set included sequences and structures of proteins that had been experimentally tested and verified plus a large sequence collection (>400 sequences) from eight insect orders (stick insects, cockroaches, termites, thrips, true bugs, sawflies, wasps, bees, ants, beetles, butterflies, moths, and flies) that have been deposited to UniProt and annotated as IDS enzymes yet have not been experimentally tested. Further, our project partners isolated new IDS-like sequences from terpene-producing insects in search of proteins that have TPS function and used by insects for chemical communication.

Using our data resources, we applied a combination of biochemical domain knowledge (structural biology and mechanistic enzymology) with bioinformatics tools to develop an evolutionary hypothesis for the emergence of TPS function in insects. Specifically, we i) created structural models of insect IDS and TPS proteins from our sequence set, ii) computed residue interaction networks ? maps that show how different parts of the protein are connected with each other and to the substrates they bind and act on, iii) compared TPS and IDS reaction mechanisms, and iv) applied biochemical domain knowledge to pinpoint critical regions in structure based on mechanistic differences. We discovered six, highly conserved isopentyl diphosphate binding motifs (IBMs) in IDS proteins that bind to isopentyl diphosphate (IPP) as a substrate. According to our structure-mechanism-evolution model, TPS enzymes must ?loose? IBM motifs in order to gain TPS function.

We validated our hypothesis by analyzing IDS enzymes from diverse organisms (plants, animals, fungi, and viruses) that range from 9 to 98% pairwise sequence identity. All IDSs contain conserved IBM motifs. Strikingly, all previously tested insect TPSs lost several IBM motifs due to mutations, insertions or deletions ? a clear signature of evolutionary change. Our model was further validated by characterizing newly discovered proteins in the project. Extending our analysis, we constructed the most comprehensive family tree (phylogeny) of insect IDS sequences (430 full length sequences) and used IBM motifs to predict the function of TPSs. Based on our analysis, we identified 126 putative insect TPSs and inferred multiple, independent TPS emergence events across the class of insects. Our study resulted in the most comprehensive analysis of insect chemical communication to date and paves the way for future gene discovery efforts in insects and diverse terpene-producing organisms in the biosphere.

The broader impacts of our project are numerous. This project has produced the most comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of the insect a-domain proteins (encompassing IDS and TPS enzymes) to date. When made available via publication and posting on our project web site, this resource will positively impact the fields of insect chemical communication and protein evolution. Our phylogenetic tree can be interpreted in light of other investigations, including ?The origins of flowering plants and pollinators? (recently published in Science; 19 JUNE 2020, VOL 368, ISSUE 6497, pg. 1306), to make inferences on the role of chemical communication in the co-evolution of insects and flowering plants. Our protein structural and network models provide a 3-D framework for visualizing subsets of the phylogenetic tree that we successfully used to develop hypotheses about the underlying sequence changes and potential evolutionary routes to TPS function ? a resource that will impact other fellow investigators in the chemical ecology field. Finally, our approach using mechanism and structure together with bioinformatics to define critical motifs is generalizable to other enzyme families under evolutionary pressure to develop new functions.
